7.title:  Zig et Puce
7.author: [No author]

contents.author: Thierry Groensteen. p. 8-17 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 1 (Jan. 1996).
contents.title: Articles About. "Hergé Débiteur de Saint-Ogan"

notes: Begins: "La dette de Tintin envers Zig et Puce n'a jamais été clairement établie ni suffisamment soulignée. En prendre la mesure permet de mieux apprécier l'ampleur du séisme que représente Hergé dans l'histoire de la bande dessinée."

English summary (from p. 138): "Hergé's Debt to Saint-Ogan. Four years before the creation of Tintin, the Frenchman Alain Saint-Ogan's adventures of two boys (Zig and Puce) and a penguin, were enjoying triumphant success. Saint-Ogan's influence on Hergé's graphic style has often been highlighted, but Thierry Groensteen goes further and shows how the young Belgian artist's imagination was veritably colonized by the characters, situations and narrative rhythms which made the success of 'Zig et Puce'. The first episodes of Tintin owe much to this source, from which Hergé later detached himself and went on to leave an important personal legacy to the world of comics."

220.title:  Zigmund. "Freak Show"
220.author: written by Bruce Jones ; illustrated by Berni Wrightson ; colored by Michelle Wrightson
220.appears_in: p. 12-18 in Heavy Metal, v. 6, no. 7 (Oct. 1982).
notes: "The story so far: The dark stranger told of Lila who, in running from her past, stumbled upon 'Valker's Wretches.' They lived together, the lithe, blonde woman named Lila, the tall, dark-bearded man named Valker. They lived with Deja the frog-girl and Robin the bird-boy and Posie the pinhead and Wilhelm the worm and George and Zigmund and all the other misshapen freaks of nature who followed them."
"To be continued."
